XX, a 45-year-old male with a past medical history of hypertension, presents to his primary care doctor with a three-day history of malaise, headache, body aches, subjective fever, and non-productive cough. He is diagnosed with influenza confirmed by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction testing but is otherwise clinically stable and does not require hospitalization. Which of the following is most appropriate for XX at this time?
Option A: Do not initiate any antiviral medication

question: GT is a 33-year-old nurse with a positive tuberculin skin test of greater than 5 mm. A T-SPOT test confirms she has latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI). GT has high blood pressure and takes lisinopril. Additionally, she takes ethinyl estradiol/levonorgestrel for birth control and to help regulate menstruation. She takes ibuprofen for occasional muscle aches; otherwise, she is healthy and would like to begin treatment for LTBI. Which regimen would be most appropriate for GT?
Option A: Rifapentine 600 mg and isoniazid 300 mg once weekly for 3 months
Option C: Rifampin 600 mg and pyrazinamide for 2 months

question: Which regimen is most appropriate during the continuation phase for treating a 75-kg patient co-infected with pulmonary TB and HIV? The patient is not taking any antiretrovirals for treatment of HIV.
Option A: Rifampin 600 mg and isoniazid 300 mg daily
Option B: Rifabutin 300 mg and isoniazid 900 twice weekly
Option C: Rifapentine 600 mg and isoniazid 900 mg once weekly
Option D: Rifampin 600 mg and isoniazid 900 mg twice weekly

question: LM is a 28-year-old man with HIV with a diagnosis of active TB. He currently takes a daily TB regimen of rifabutin 150 mg, isoniazid 300 mg, pyrazinamide 1500 mg, and ethambutol 800 mg and an HIV regimen of raltegravir 400 mg twice daily plus 200 mg emtricitabine/300 mg tenofovir disoproxil fumarate. He returns for a follow-up appointment 1 month after beginning his TB treatment with complaints of blurred vision. Further testing shows he has lost the ability to detect the color green. Which medication is most likely responsible?
Which scenario is not considered as an Surgical Site Infection?
Option A:

Organisms isolated from an aseptically obtained culture of fluid from

Why are antibiograms important in clinical practice?
Option A: To identify the specific genetic mutations responsible for antibiotic resistance
Option B: To monitor trends in antibiotic side effects across hospital units
Option C: To assess the clinical efficacy of antibiotics in individual patients
Option D: To guide empiric antibiotic therapy based on local resistance patterns

question: What is the correct definition of MDR (Multidrug-Resistant) pathogens?
Option A: Resistant to at least one agent in three or more antimicrobial categories
Option B: Resistant to all agents within a single antimicrobial class
Option C: Resistant to all but two or fewer antimicrobial categories
Option D: Resistant to at least two agents in two or more antimicrobial categories
